channel.title: Professional Etiquette for PhDs | Emory Economics PhD Workshop

item.title: Good Examples of Bad Behaviors
item.description: Oh man, there are some strange stories out there. Let’s talk about just a few examples of things that you definitely should not do.

item.title: How to Keep Yourself (Somewhat) Organized
item.description:
If you don’t already, you’ll eventually feel pulled in many directions between teaching, service, and research. You’ll have similar pressures outside of academia. Here, we’ll talk about different organization strategies and what might work best for you.

View slides in new window

item.title: Professional rules to live by
item.description:
We’ll go through some specific examples of what not to do and some specific strategies that I think can help us all be better professionals. But I think a lot about “being professional” can be summarized in three simple rules:

Rules of Etiquette
1. Give others the benefit of the doubt
2. Always assume you made the mistake until proven otherwise
3. Respect others’ time

“Others” means everyone, not just “other professors”

Follow the links to the left for some extra information in specific areas.

item.title: Tips for Email Etiquette
item.description:
Ugh, emails. No one likes email. But it can be extremely efficient if we would all just try a little. Here, we’ll talk about some strategies for keeping it professional in your email communication and hopefully minimizing some otherwise wasted time.

View slides in new window

item.title: Tips for Attending Meetings
item.description:
If email is useful, it’s as a substitute for meetings. But meetings are necessary part of any workplace. Here, we’ll talk about some basic norms of office meetings.

View slides in new window

item.title: Contribute Positively to Your Office or Department Culture
item.description:
An “office culture” is hard to define. It’s basically a system of values, shared assumptions, and group norms. I believe that strong, positive culture can help develop junior faculty, improve teaching, and even improve our research. There’s certainly plenty of evidence that a strong culture helps in a traditional office setting.

As academics, we’ve often developed some odd work habits. Here, we’ll talk about some things we should consider and try to improve upon if we want to enjoy our workplace.

View slides in new window
